nodes.label: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence DNA methylation patterns triggered by ...

properties.title: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence DNA methylation patterns triggered by galactic cosmic radiation
properties.abstract: Despite surging interest in space travel in recent decades, the impacts of prolonged, elevated exposure to galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) on human health remain poorly understood. This form of ionizing radiation causes significant changes to biological systems including damage to DNA structure by altering epigenetic phenotype with emphasis on DNA methylation. Building on previous work by Kennedy et al. (Sci Rep 8(1): 6709. 10.1038/S41598-018-24755-8), we evaluated spatial DNA methylation patterns triggered by high-LET (56Fe, 28Si) and low-LET (X-ray) radiation and the influence of chromosome positioning and epigenetic architecture in distinct radial layers of cell nucleus. Next, we validated our results using gene expression data of mice irradiated with simulated GCR and JAXA astronauts. We showed that primarily 56Fe induces a persistent DNA methylation increase whereas 28Si and X-ray induce a decrease DNA methylation which is not persistent with time. Moreover, we highlighted the role of nuclear chromatin architecture in cell response to external radiation. In summary, our study provides novel insights towards epigenetic and transcriptomic response as well as chromatin multidimensional structure influence on galactic cosmic radiation damage.
properties.summary: This study investigated how high-LET (56Fe, 28Si) and low-LET (X-ray) radiation, mimicking galactic cosmic radiation (GCR), influence DNA methylation patterns and the role of chromosome positioning and epigenetic architecture in cell nuclei. The research found that 56Fe primarily induces a persistent DNA methylation increase, whereas 28Si and X-ray lead to a non-persistent decrease. These findings, validated with data from irradiated mice and JAXA astronauts, highlight the crucial role of nuclear chromatin architecture in cellular response to external radiation and provide novel insights into GCR damage mechanisms.
properties.impact: This publication significantly advances the scientific understanding of galactic cosmic radiation's impact on human health by detailing specific epigenetic and transcriptomic responses and the critical role of nuclear chromatin architecture. Practically, these insights are vital for assessing health risks in prolonged space missions, aiding in the development of countermeasures and monitoring strategies for astronauts. Furthermore, the findings on radiation-induced epigenetic changes could inform broader radiation biology research, including terrestrial applications and future studies on long-term health effects and specific chromatin interactions.
properties.original_title: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence DNA methylation patterns triggered by galactic cosmic radiation

nodes.label: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2: host extracellular to systemic effects of SA...

properties.title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2: host extracellular to systemic effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection
properties.abstract: COVID-19, the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2, has caused significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. The betacoronavirus continues to evolve with global health implications as we race to learn more to curb its transmission, evolution, and sequelae. The focus of this review, the second of a three-part series, is on the biological effects of the SARS-CoV-2 virus on post-acute disease in the context of tissue and organ adaptations and damage. We highlight the current knowledge and describe how virological, animal, and clinical studies have shed light on the mechanisms driving the varied clinical diagnoses and observations of COVID-19 patients. Moreover, we describe how investigations into SARS-CoV-2 effects have informed the understanding of viral pathogenesis and provide innovative pathways for future research on the mechanisms of viral diseases.
properties.summary: This review, the second in a three-part series, comprehensively examines the host's extracellular to systemic responses to SARS-CoV-2 infection, with a focus on post-acute disease, tissue, and organ adaptations and damage. It synthesizes current knowledge from virological, animal, and clinical studies to elucidate the mechanisms driving varied COVID-19 clinical diagnoses and observations. The publication aims to inform the understanding of viral pathogenesis and provide innovative pathways for future research on the mechanisms of viral diseases.
properties.impact: This publication significantly advances the understanding of SARS-CoV-2 pathogenesis and its widespread biological effects, including long COVID-19, which is critically relevant for astronaut health during long-duration space missions. By integrating diverse research from cellular to systemic levels, it informs the development of countermeasures and health monitoring strategies for viral threats in space and on Earth. The comprehensive nature of the review offers innovative directions for future research into viral disease mechanisms, with broad implications for public health and medicine.
properties.original_title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2: Host extracellular to systemic effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection

nodes.label: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are altered by spaceflight

properties.title: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are altered by spaceflight
properties.abstract: Human space exploration poses inherent risks to astronauts’ health, leading to molecular changes that can significantly impact their well-being. These alterations encompass genomic instability, mitochondrial dysfunction, increased inflammation, homeostatic dysregulation, and various epigenomic changes. Remarkably, these changes bear similarities to those observed during the aging process on Earth. However, our understanding of the connection between these molecular shifts and disease development in space remains limited. Frailty syndrome, a clinical syndrome associated with biological aging, has not been comprehensively investigated during spaceflight. To bridge this knowledge gap, we leveraged murine data obtained from NASA’s GeneLab, along with astronaut data gathered from the JAXA and Inspiration4 missions. Our objective was to assess the presence of biological markers and pathways related to frailty, aging, and sarcopenia within the spaceflight context. Through our analysis, we identified notable changes in gene expression patterns that may be indicative of the development of a frailty-like condition during space missions. These findings suggest that the parallels between spaceflight and the aging process may extend to encompass frailty as well. Consequently, further investigations exploring the utility of a frailty index in monitoring astronaut health appear to be warranted.
properties.summary: This study leveraged murine data from NASA’s GeneLab and astronaut data from JAXA and Inspiration4 missions to assess biological markers and pathways related to frailty, aging, and sarcopenia during spaceflight. Researchers identified notable changes in gene expression patterns indicative of a frailty-like condition, including differentially expressed frailty and sarcopenia biomarkers in rodent and human muscles, enriched inflammatory responses, and dysregulated metabolic functions. These findings suggest that spaceflight parallels with aging may extend to encompass frailty, warranting further investigation into a frailty index for astronaut health monitoring.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this research significantly advances our understanding of spaceflight's molecular effects by linking them directly to biological aging and frailty, utilizing a robust dataset from both animal models and human missions. Practically, identifying these frailty-like changes has direct implications for monitoring astronaut health during long-duration missions and could inform the development of targeted countermeasures. Broader implications include insights into terrestrial aging and frailty mechanisms, as spaceflight acts as an accelerated model of aging, highlighting the utility of a frailty index for health assessment both in space and on Earth.
properties.original_title: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are altered by spaceflight

nodes.label: Space radiation damage rescued by inhibition of key spaceflight associated miRNAs

properties.title: Space radiation damage rescued by inhibition of key spaceflight associated miRNAs
properties.abstract: Our previous research revealed a key microRNA signature that is associated with spaceflight that can be used as a biomarker and to develop countermeasure treatments to mitigate the damage caused by space radiation. Here, we expand on this work to determine the biological factors rescued by the countermeasure treatment. We performed RNA-sequencing and transcriptomic analysis on 3D microvessel cell cultures exposed to simulated deep space radiation (0.5 Gy of Galactic Cosmic Radiation) with and without the antagonists to three microRNAs: miR-16-5p, miR-125b-5p, and let-7a-5p (i.e., antagomirs). Significant reduction of inflammation and DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) activity and rescue of mitochondria functions are observed after antagomir treatment. Using data from astronaut participants in the NASA Twin Study, Inspiration4, and JAXA missions, we reveal the genes and pathways implicated in the action of these antagomirs are altered in humans. Our findings indicate a countermeasure strategy that can potentially be utilized by astronauts in spaceflight missions to mitigate space radiation damage.
properties.summary: This study investigated the biological factors rescued by antagomirs (targeting miR-16-5p, miR-125b-5p, and let-7a-5p) as a countermeasure against simulated deep space radiation (0.5 Gy of Galactic Cosmic Radiation) in 3D microvessel cell cultures. Key findings include significant reduction of inflammation and DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) activity, and rescue of mitochondrial functions after treatment. Human data from astronaut participants (NASA Twin Study, Inspiration4, JAXA missions) corroborated these findings, indicating a promising strategy to mitigate space radiation damage for astronauts.
properties.impact: Published in Nat Commun, this research significantly advances the scientific understanding of molecular mechanisms of space radiation damage and miRNA-mediated rescue pathways. It proposes a critical practical application by identifying a potential countermeasure strategy using specific antagomirs to mitigate space radiation damage, which is vital for astronaut health during long-duration space missions. The findings also hold broader implications for developing terrestrial radiation protection strategies and guiding future space biology research into molecular countermeasures.
properties.original_title: Space radiation damage rescued by inhibition of key spaceflight associated miRNAs

nodes.label: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration

properties.title: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration
properties.abstract: Mounting ambitions and capabilities for public and private, non-government sector crewed space exploration bring with them an increasingly diverse set of space travelers, raising new and nontrivial ethical, legal, and medical policy and practice concerns which are still relatively underexplored. In this piece, we lay out several pressing issues related to ethical considerations for selecting space travelers and conducting human subject research on them, especially in the context of non-governmental and commercial/private space operations. New and dynamically changing opportunities for commercial/private and civilian spaceflight raise the need for an examination of how to ethically guide space industry and community. This Perspective explores such considerations with respect to space traveler selection and human subject research.
properties.summary: This publication identifies and explores underexplored ethical, legal, and medical policy concerns arising from the increasing diversity of space travelers and the rapid growth of non-governmental space exploration capabilities. It specifically focuses on ethical considerations for selecting space travelers and conducting human subject research in commercial and private space operations. The work emphasizes the critical need for ethical guidance to navigate the new and dynamically changing opportunities within the evolving space industry.
properties.impact: This publication holds significant scientific value by systematically addressing the complex and emerging ethical, legal, and medical challenges of non-governmental human spaceflight, an area previously underexplored. Its practical applications are immediate and crucial for informing policy and practice for commercial spaceflight companies, medical practitioners, and regulatory bodies involved in space traveler selection and human subject research protocols. The broader implications include establishing foundational ethical frameworks for future space exploration, potentially influencing international policy, and fostering responsible development across the entire space industry.
properties.original_title: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration

nodes.label: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the D...

properties.title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model
properties.abstract: While it has been shown that astronauts suffer immune disorders after spaceflight, the underlying causes are still poorly understood and there are many variables to consider when investigating the immune system in a complex environment. Additionally, there is growing evidence that suggests that not only is the immune system being altered, but the pathogens that infect the host are significantly influenced by spaceflight and ground-based spaceflight conditions. In this study, we demonstrate that Serratia marcescens (strain Db11) was significantly more lethal to Drosophila melanogaster after growth on the International Space Station than ground-based controls, but the increased virulence phenotype of S. marcescens did not persist after the bacterial cultures were passaged on the ground. Increased virulence was also observed in bacteria that were grown in simulated microgravity conditions on the ground using the rotating wall vessel. Increased virulence of the space-flown bacteria was similar in magnitude between wild-type flies and those that were mutants for the well-characterized immune pathways Imd and Toll, suggesting that changes to the host immune system after infection are likely not a major factor contributing towards increased susceptibility of ground-reared flies infected with space-flown bacteria. Characterization of the bacteria shows that at later timepoints spaceflight bacteria grew at a greater rate than ground controls in vitro, and in the host. These results suggest complex physiological changes occurring in pathogenic bacteria in space environments, and there may be novel mechanisms mediating these physiological effects that need to be characterized.
properties.summary: This study investigated how spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions impact the virulence of the bacterium *Serratia marcescens* using a *Drosophila melanogaster* infection model. Key findings revealed that *S. marcescens* grown on the International Space Station became significantly more lethal to flies compared to ground controls, a virulence increase also observed under simulated microgravity on Earth. The increased lethality did not persist after ground passaging and was similar in magnitude between wild-type and immune-deficient flies, suggesting that changes to the pathogen itself, rather than the host immune system, primarily contribute to increased susceptibility, alongside observed greater bacterial growth rates at later timepoints *in vitro* and *in vivo*.
properties.impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of how space environments can alter pathogen characteristics, specifically increasing bacterial virulence and growth rates, which is crucial for astronaut health and the planning of long-duration space missions. By demonstrating that spaceflight can intrinsically enhance a pathogen's lethality and growth largely independent of host immune system changes, it highlights a critical area for novel countermeasure development to protect crew. The findings also open new avenues for future research into the complex physiological mechanisms underlying bacterial adaptation in microgravity, potentially informing broader terrestrial studies on microbial stress responses and pathogenicity.
properties.original_title: Innate immune responses of Drosophila melanogaster are altered by spaceflight.

nodes.label: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility and Initiates Remodeling in Drosoph...

properties.title: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility and Initiates Remodeling in Drosophila
properties.abstract: Understanding the effects of microgravity on human organs is crucial to exploration of low-earth orbit, the moon, and beyond. Drosophila can be sent to space in large numbers to examine the effects of microgravity on heart structure and function, which is fundamentally conserved from flies to humans. Flies reared in microgravity exhibit cardiac constriction with myofibrillar remodeling and diminished output. RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) in isolated hearts revealed reduced expression of sarcomeric/extracellular matrix (ECM) genes and dramatically increased proteasomal gene expression, consistent with the observed compromised, smaller hearts and suggesting abnormal proteostasis. This was examined further on a second flight in which we found dramatically elevated proteasome aggregates co-localizing with increased amyloid and polyQ deposits. Remarkably, in long-QT causing sei/hERG mutants, proteasomal gene expression at 1g, although less than the wild-type expression, was nevertheless increased in microgravity. Therefore, cardiac remodeling and proteostatic stress may be a fundamental response of heart muscle to microgravity.
properties.summary: This study investigated the effects of prolonged microgravity exposure on heart structure and function using Drosophila as a model system. Key findings revealed that flies in microgravity developed cardiac constriction, myofibrillar remodeling, and diminished cardiac output, accompanied by reduced sarcomeric/extracellular matrix gene expression and dramatically increased proteasomal gene expression, consistent with compromised hearts and abnormal proteostasis. These observations were further supported by elevated proteasome aggregates and increased amyloid/polyQ deposits, indicating that cardiac remodeling and proteostatic stress represent a fundamental response of heart muscle to microgravity.
properties.impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of microgravity's impact on the cardiovascular system by identifying proteostatic stress and cardiac remodeling as fundamental responses. The use of Drosophila provides a powerful model for high-throughput space biology research, crucial for understanding astronaut health risks during deep-space missions. These insights have practical applications for developing countermeasures against cardiac dysfunction in space and may offer broader implications for terrestrial cardiac diseases involving proteostasis.
properties.original_title: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility and Initiates Remodeling in Drosophila

nodes.label: Bundling up the Role of the Actin Cytoskeleton in Primary Root Growth

properties.title: Bundling up the Role of the Actin Cytoskeleton in Primary Root Growth
properties.abstract: Primary root growth is required by the plant to anchor in the soil and reach out for nutrients and water, while dealing with obstacles. Efficient root elongation and bending depends upon the coordinated action of environmental sensing, signal transduction, and growth responses. The actin cytoskeleton is a highly plastic network that constitutes a point of integration for environmental stimuli and hormonal pathways. In this review, we present a detailed compilation highlighting the importance of the actin cytoskeleton during primary root growth and we describe how actin-binding proteins, plant hormones, and actin-disrupting drugs affect root growth and root actin. We also discuss the feedback loop between actin and root responses to light and gravity. Actin affects cell division and elongation through the control of its own organization. We remark upon the importance of longitudinally oriented actin bundles as a hallmark of cell elongation as well as the role of the actin cytoskeleton in protein trafficking and vacuolar reshaping during this process. The actin network is shaped by a plethora of actin-binding proteins; however, there is still a large gap in connecting the molecular function of these proteins with their developmental effects. Here, we summarize their function and known effects on primary root growth with a focus on their high level of specialization. Light and gravity are key factors that help us understand root growth directionality. The response of the root to gravity relies on hormonal, particularly auxin, homeostasis, and the actin cytoskeleton. Actin is necessary for the perception of the gravity stimulus via the repositioning of sedimenting statoliths, but it is also involved in mediating the growth response via the trafficking of auxin transporters and cell elongation. Furthermore, auxin and auxin analogs can affect the composition of the actin network, indicating a potential feedback loop. Light, in its turn, affects actin organization and hence, root growth, although its precise role remains largely unknown. Recently, fundamental studies with the latest techniques have given us more in-depth knowledge of the role and organization of actin in the coordination of root growth; however, there remains a lot to discover, especially in how actin organization helps cell shaping, and therefore root growth.
properties.summary: This review compiles current knowledge on the actin cytoskeleton's critical role in primary root growth, emphasizing its function as an integrator of environmental stimuli and hormonal pathways. It highlights actin's necessity for cell elongation through organized bundles, protein trafficking, and vacuolar reshaping, and its involvement in gravitropism via statolith repositioning and auxin transport, forming an auxin-actin feedback loop. The publication identifies significant gaps in understanding the molecular functions of actin-binding proteins and the precise mechanisms by which actin organization drives cell shaping during root development.
properties.impact: This review significantly advances fundamental plant biology by synthesizing the intricate roles of the actin cytoskeleton in primary root growth and its integration of environmental and hormonal cues, while also clearly outlining crucial knowledge gaps. Practically, a deeper understanding of these basic processes, particularly gravitropism and light responses, is vital for developing resilient plant-based life support systems for long-duration space missions and for enhancing crop performance in diverse terrestrial and extraterrestrial agricultural settings. The work provides a critical foundation and direction for future research into the precise molecular and cellular mechanisms governing actin organization and root development.
properties.original_title: Regulation of plant gravity sensing and signaling by the actin cytoskeleton.

nodes.label: HLB1 Is a Tetratricopeptide Repeat Domain-Containing Protein That Operates at the Intersection of th...

properties.title: HLB1 Is a Tetratricopeptide Repeat Domain-Containing Protein That Operates at the Intersection of the Exocytic and Endocytic Pathways at the TGN/EE in Arabidopsis
properties.abstract:
A forward-genetic screen for Arabidopsis mutants hypersensitive to latrunculin B identifies HLB1 as a plant-specific protein that functions in post-Golgi traffic.

The endomembrane system plays essential roles in plant development, but the proteome responsible for its function and organization remains largely uncharacterized in plants. Here, we identified and characterized the HYPERSENSITIVE TO LATRUNCULIN B1 (HLB1) protein isolated through a forward-genetic screen in Arabidopsis thaliana for mutants with heightened sensitivity to actin-disrupting drugs. HLB1 is a plant-specific tetratricopeptide repeat domain-containing protein of unknown function encoded by a single Arabidopsis gene. HLB1 associated with the trans-Golgi network (TGN)/early endosome (EE) and tracked along filamentous actin, indicating that it could link post-Golgi traffic with the actin cytoskeleton in plants. HLB1 was found to interact with the ADP-ribosylation-factor guanine nucleotide exchange factor, MIN7/BEN1 (HOPM INTERACTOR7/BREFELDIN A-VISUALIZED ENDOCYTIC TRAFFICKING DEFECTIVE1) by coimmunoprecipitation. The min7/ben1 mutant phenocopied the mild root developmental defects and latrunculin B hypersensitivity of hlb1, and analyses of a hlb1/ min7/ben1 double mutant showed that hlb1 and min7/ben1 operate in common genetic pathways. Based on these data, we propose that HLB1 together with MIN7/BEN1 form a complex with actin to modulate the function of the TGN/EE at the intersection of the exocytic and endocytic pathways in plants.
properties.summary: This study identified and characterized HYPERSENSITIVE TO LATRUNCULIN B1 (HLB1), a plant-specific tetratricopeptide repeat domain-containing protein in Arabidopsis, through a forward-genetic screen for mutants hypersensitive to actin-disrupting drugs. HLB1 functions in post-Golgi traffic, associating with the trans-Golgi network/early endosome (TGN/EE) and interacting with the ADP-ribosylation-factor guanine nucleotide exchange factor, MIN7/BEN1, and the actin cytoskeleton. The research proposes that HLB1 and MIN7/BEN1 form an actin-associated complex to modulate TGN/EE function at the intersection of the exocytic and endocytic pathways in plants.
properties.impact: This research significantly advances fundamental understanding of the plant endomembrane system and protein trafficking by characterizing a novel plant-specific protein, HLB1, and its role in TGN/EE function. While a basic science study in Arabidopsis, this knowledge is critical for understanding plant development and optimizing plant-based life support systems and agriculture essential for long-duration space missions. This foundational work also establishes a basis for future investigations into how these cellular processes might be affected by environmental stressors encountered in space, such as microgravity or radiation, influencing plant health and productivity.
properties.original_title: HLB1 Is a Tetratricopeptide Repeat Domain-Containing Protein That Operates at the Intersection of the Exocytic and Endocytic Pathways at the TGN/EE in Arabidopsis

nodes.label: ERULUS Is a Plasma Membrane-Localized Receptor-Like Kinase That Specifies Root Hair Growth by Mainta...

properties.title: ERULUS Is a Plasma Membrane-Localized Receptor-Like Kinase That Specifies Root Hair Growth by Maintaining Tip-Focused Cytoplasmic Calcium Oscillations
properties.abstract:
Root hairs are single-cell cylindrical projections that expand the effective radius of the root. In doing so, they play crucial roles in the uptake of water and nutrients from the soil, especially under conditions in which such resources are limiting (Carminati et al., 2017). Root hairs expand by tip growth, a process that involves the targeted delivery and secretion of vesicles to the cell apex. As a result, root hairs attain lengths that are several times their widths (Chebli et al., 2013). In tip-growing cells, cargo transported by tip-targeted vesicles consist of an assortment of carbohydrate precursors that are needed for the assembly and remodeling of the apical cell wall (Gu and Nielsen, 2013). Research spanning several decades has led to the identification of multiple components of the tip growth machinery including protein modulators of cytoskeletal organization, membrane trafficking, cytoplasmic calcium ([Ca2+]cyt) signaling, and phosphoinositide metabolism (Cole and Fowler, 2006; Rounds and Bezanilla, 2013).

In recent years, plant malectin-like receptor kinases, also known as Catharanthus roseus receptor-like kinases (CrRLK1Ls; Franck et al., 2018), have been shown to regulate tip growth in root hairs and pollen tubes (Duan et al., 2010; Bai et al., 2014; Haruta et al., 2014; Ge et al., 2017; Schoenaers et al., 2018). In one noteworthy study, Bai et al. (2014) reported that a CrRLK1L, which they named [Ca2+]cyt-associated protein kinase 1 (CAP1), modulates root hair growth by maintaining ammonium (NH4+) homeostasis. CAP1 is also known as ERULUS (ERU), named after the son of FERONIA (FER), a widely studied member of the CrRLK1L family (Haruta et al., 2014). In Arabidopsis thaliana, cap1/eru loss-of-function mutants have short and irregularly shaped root hairs consistent with a role of CAP1/ERU as a positive regulator of root hair growth (Bai et al., 2014; Haruta et al., 2014; Schoenaers et al., 2018). Bai et al. (2014) proposed a model wherein CAP1/ERU functions in maintaining root hair growth under high NH4+ environments by sensing cytoplasmic NH4+. Sensing of cytoplasmic NH4+ by CAP1/ERU then triggers signaling events that lead to NH4+ sequestration into the vacuole, making it less toxic to the cell. The model postulates that toxic levels of NH4+ accumulate in the cytoplasm of cap1/eru loss-of-function mutants, resulting in the disappearance of tip-focused [Ca2+]cyt gradients, and because of this lack of tip-focused [Ca2+]cyt gradients, their root hairs cease to expand (Bai et al., 2014). In this letter, we question the proposed role of CAP1/ERU in NH4+ homeostasis based on our studies of a new eru-3 mutant allele, showing that CAP1/ERU is instead localized to the plasma membrane (PM) and its function is linked to tip-focused [Ca2+]cyt oscillations. This is further supported by recent work on the eru-2 mutant by Schoenaers et al. (2018), as described below.
properties.summary: This NASA Space Biology publication investigates the function and localization of the receptor-like kinase ERULUS (ERU), also known as CAP1, which specifies root hair growth. The study found that ERULUS is localized to the plasma membrane and its function is critically linked to maintaining tip-focused cytoplasmic calcium oscillations, a process essential for root hair expansion. This finding challenges and refines a previous model that proposed ERULUS's role in ammonium homeostasis.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this research significantly advances our fundamental understanding of plant cell development, specifically the complex interplay between receptor-like kinases and calcium signaling in regulating tip growth in root hairs. Published in 'Plant Cell,' a highly regarded journal, it underscores the importance of precise cellular mechanisms. Practically, optimizing root hair growth and nutrient uptake is crucial for developing efficient plant-based life support systems and food production for long-duration space missions, directly aligning with NASA's space biology objectives. Broader implications include improving agricultural practices on Earth for enhanced crop nutrient uptake and stress resilience.
properties.original_title: ERULUS is a plasma membrane-localized receptor-like kinase that specifies root hair growth by maintaining tip-focused cytoplasmic calcium oscillations.

nodes.label: Brassinosteroids Inhibit Autotropic Root Straightening by Modifying Filamentous-Actin Organization a...

properties.title: Brassinosteroids Inhibit Autotropic Root Straightening by Modifying Filamentous-Actin Organization and Dynamics
properties.abstract: When positioned horizontally, roots grow down toward the direction of gravity. This phenomenon, called gravitropism, is influenced by most of the major plant hormones including brassinosteroids. Epi-brassinolide (eBL) was previously shown to enhance root gravitropism, a phenomenon similar to the response of roots exposed to the actin inhibitor, latrunculin B (LatB). This led us to hypothesize that eBL might enhance root gravitropism through its effects on filamentous-actin (F-actin). This hypothesis was tested by comparing gravitropic responses of maize (Zea mays) roots treated with eBL or LatB. LatB- and eBL-treated roots displayed similar enhanced downward growth compared with controls when vertical roots were oriented horizontally. Moreover, the effects of the two compounds on root growth directionality were more striking on a slowly-rotating two-dimensional clinostat. Both compounds inhibited autotropism, a process in which the root straightened after the initial gravistimulus was withdrawn by clinorotation. Although eBL reduced F-actin density in chemically-fixed Z. mays roots, the impact was not as strong as that of LatB. Modification of F-actin organization after treatment with both compounds was also observed in living roots of barrel medic (Medicago truncatula) seedlings expressing genetically encoded F-actin reporters. Like in fixed Z. mays roots, eBL effects on F-actin in living M. truncatula roots were modest compared with those of LatB. Furthermore, live cell imaging revealed a decrease in global F-actin dynamics in hypocotyls of etiolated M. truncatula seedlings treated with eBL compared to controls. Collectively, our data indicate that eBL-and LatB-induced enhancement of root gravitropism can be explained by inhibited autotropic root straightening, and that eBL affects this process, in part, by modifying F-actin organization and dynamics.
properties.summary: This study investigated whether the plant hormone epi-brassinolide (eBL) enhances root gravitropism by modifying filamentous-actin (F-actin). Researchers found that eBL and the actin inhibitor latrunculin B (LatB) similarly enhanced downward root growth and inhibited autotropism in maize and barrel medic roots when gravistimulus was withdrawn by clinorotation. While eBL modestly reduced F-actin density and dynamics compared to LatB, the data collectively indicate that eBL's enhancement of root gravitropism is partly explained by its effect on F-actin organization and dynamics, leading to inhibited autotropic root straightening.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this research advances our understanding of the complex interplay between plant hormones, the actin cytoskeleton, and gravity perception in roots, particularly concerning the mechanism of gravitropic response and autotropism. For space missions, these findings are highly significant as understanding how plants sense and respond to gravity is crucial for developing robust plant growth systems in microgravity or altered gravity environments for long-duration space travel and extraterrestrial habitats. By elucidating how brassinosteroids and F-actin influence root directionality, this work could inform strategies to optimize plant resource allocation and growth efficiency for food production and life support beyond Earth.
properties.original_title: Brassinosteroids inhibit autotropic root straightening by modifying filamentous-actin organization and dynamics.

nodes.label: Cell Type-Specific Imaging of Calcium Signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana Seedling Roots Using GCaMP3

properties.title: Cell Type-Specific Imaging of Calcium Signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana Seedling Roots Using GCaMP3
properties.abstract: Cytoplasmic calcium ([Ca2+]cyt) is a well-characterized second messenger in eukaryotic cells. An elevation in [Ca2+]cyt levels is one of the earliest responses in plant cells after exposure to a range of environmental stimuli. Advances in understanding the role of [Ca2+]cyt in plant development has been facilitated by the use of genetically-encoded reporters such as GCaMP. Most of these studies have relied on promoters such as Cauliflower Mosaic Virus (35S) and Ubiquitin10 (UBQ10) to drive expression of GCaMP in all cell/tissue types. Plant organs such as roots consist of various cell types that likely exhibit unique [Ca2+]cyt responses to exogenous and endogenous signals. However, few studies have addressed this question. Here, we introduce a set of Arabidopsis thaliana lines expressing GCaMP3 in five root cell types including the columella, endodermis, cortex, epidermis, and trichoblasts. We found similarities and differences in the [Ca2+]cyt signature among these root cell types when exposed to adenosine tri-phosphate (ATP), glutamate, aluminum, and salt, which are known to trigger [Ca2+]cyt increases in root cells. These cell type-targeted GCaMP3 lines provide a new resource that should enable more in depth studies that address how a particular environmental stimulus is linked to specific root developmental pathways via [Ca2+]cyt.
properties.summary: This study addressed the question of unique cytoplasmic calcium ([Ca2+]cyt) responses in different root cell types of *Arabidopsis thaliana* by developing novel lines expressing the GCaMP3 reporter in five specific root cell types (columella, endodermis, cortex, epidermis, and trichoblasts). The researchers observed both similarities and differences in the [Ca2+]cyt signature among these cell types when exposed to environmental stimuli such as ATP, glutamate, aluminum, and salt. These cell type-targeted GCaMP3 lines provide a new resource to facilitate more in-depth studies linking specific environmental stimuli to root developmental pathways via [Ca2+]cyt.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this publication significantly advances the methodology and understanding of plant cell biology by providing a precise tool for cell type-specific calcium signaling analysis, overcoming previous limitations of ubiquitous GCaMP expression. For space missions, understanding how different plant root cells respond to various environmental stimuli, including stresses, is crucial for optimizing plant health and productivity in controlled environment agriculture systems like those on the ISS or future planetary habitats. Broader implications include enhancing crop resilience to terrestrial environmental challenges and guiding future research into the precise mechanisms by which [Ca2+]cyt mediates plant development in response to stimuli.
properties.original_title: Cell type-specific imaging of calcium signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana seedling roots using GCaMP3.

nodes.label: Spatial and temporal localization of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR reveal roles for these proteins in actin-...

properties.title: Spatial and temporal localization of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR reveal roles for these proteins in actin-mediated root hair development
properties.abstract: Root hairs are single-cell protrusions that enable roots to optimize nutrient and water acquisition. These structures attain their tubular shapes by confining growth to the cell apex, a process called tip growth. The actin cytoskeleton and endomembrane systems are essential for tip growth; however, little is known about how these cellular components coordinate their activities during this process. Here, we show that SPIRRIG (SPI), a beige and Chediak Higashi domain-containing protein involved in membrane trafficking, and BRK1 and SCAR2, subunits of the WAVE/SCAR (W/SC) actin nucleating promoting complex, display polarized localizations in Arabidopsis thaliana root hairs during distinct developmental stages. SPI accumulates at the root hair apex via post-Golgi compartments and positively regulates tip growth by maintaining tip-focused vesicle secretion and filamentous-actin integrity. BRK1 and SCAR2 on the other hand, mark the root hair initiation domain to specify the position of root hair emergence. Consistent with the localization data, tip growth was reduced in spi and the position of root hair emergence was disrupted in brk1 and scar1234. BRK1 depletion coincided with SPI accumulation as root hairs transitioned from initiation to tip growth. Taken together, our work uncovers a role for SPI in facilitating actin-dependent root hair development in Arabidopsis through pathways that might intersect with W/SC.
properties.summary: This study investigates the coordination between the actin cytoskeleton and endomembrane systems during *Arabidopsis thaliana* root hair tip growth, focusing on SPIRRIG (SPI) and WAVE/SCAR (W/SC) complex proteins. It reveals that SPI accumulates at the root hair apex, positively regulating tip growth by maintaining tip-focused vesicle secretion and filamentous-actin integrity, whereas W/SC subunits (BRK1, SCAR2) specify the root hair emergence position. This work uncovers a critical role for SPI in facilitating actin-dependent root hair development in Arabidopsis, potentially through pathways that intersect with W/SC.
properties.impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms governing plant root hair development, a process fundamental to nutrient and water acquisition in plants. Such knowledge is crucial for optimizing plant growth and yield in controlled environments, including those for long-duration space missions and future planetary habitats, by enabling the development of plants with enhanced resource uptake efficiency. Moreover, these findings have broader implications for terrestrial agriculture, offering potential avenues for improving crop productivity and stress resilience through targeted modifications of root architecture.
properties.original_title: Spatial and temporal localization of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR reveal roles for these proteins in actin-mediated root hair development.

nodes.label: Impact of microgravity and lunar gravity on murine skeletal and immune systems during space travel

properties.title: Impact of microgravity and lunar gravity on murine skeletal and immune systems during space travel
properties.abstract: Long-duration spaceflight creates a variety of stresses due to the unique environment, which can lead to compromised functioning of the skeletal and immune systems. However, the mechanisms by which organisms respond to this stress remain unclear. The present study aimed to investigate the impact of three different gravitational loadings (microgravity, 1/6 g [lunar gravity], and 1 g) on the behavior, bone, thymus, and spleen of mice housed for 25–35 days in the International Space Station. The bone density reduction under microgravity was mostly recovered by 1 g but only partially recovered by 1/6 g. Both 1 g and 1/6 g suppressed microgravity-induced changes in some osteoblast and osteoclast marker gene expression. Thymus atrophy induced by microgravity was half recovered by both 1 g and 1/6 g, but gene expression changes were not fully recovered by 1/6 g. While no histological changes were observed due to low gravity, alterations in gene expression were noted in the spleen. We found that in bone and thymus, lunar gravity reduced microgravity-induced histological alterations and partially reversed gene expression changes. This study highlighted organ-specific variations in responsiveness to gravity, serving as an animal test for establishing a molecular-level gravity threshold for maintaining a healthy state during future spaceflight.
properties.summary: This study investigated the impact of microgravity, lunar gravity (1/6 g), and 1 g on mouse behavior, bone, thymus, and spleen during 25-35 days on the International Space Station. Key findings indicate that microgravity-induced bone density reduction was mostly recovered by 1 g but only partially by 1/6 g, while thymus atrophy was half recovered by both 1 g and 1/6 g, though gene expression recovery varied. The research highlights organ-specific gravitational responsiveness and serves as an animal test for establishing a molecular-level gravity threshold critical for maintaining astronaut health during future spaceflight.
properties.impact: This publication significantly advances space biology by providing critical insights into the differential effects of various gravitational loads on murine skeletal and immune systems at both histological and molecular levels. Its findings are directly applicable to long-duration space missions and lunar habitation, informing the development of countermeasures and the establishment of gravity thresholds for astronaut health and mission planning. While published in Sci Rep., the unique ISS experimental setup and direct relevance to NASA's Space Biology objectives underscore its practical importance for future space exploration.

nodes.label: S. aureus MscL Is a Pentamer In Vivo but of Variable Stoichiometries In Vitro: Implications for Dete...

properties.title: S. aureus MscL Is a Pentamer In Vivo but of Variable Stoichiometries In Vitro: Implications for Detergent-Solubilized Membrane Proteins
properties.abstract: While the bacterial mechanosensitive channel of large conductance (MscL) is the best studied biological mechanosensor and serves as a paradigm for how a protein can sense and respond to membrane tension, the simple matter of its oligomeric state has led to debate, with models ranging from tetramers to hexamers. Indeed, two different oligomeric states of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscL have been resolved by X-ray crystallography: The M. tuberculosis channel (MtMscL) is a pentamer, while the S. aureus protein (SaMscL) forms a tetramer. Because several studies suggest that, like MtMscL, the E. coli MscL (EcoMscL) is a pentamer, we re-investigated the oligomeric state of SaMscL. To determine the structural organization of MscL in the cell membrane we developed a disulfide-trapping approach. Surprisingly, we found that virtually all SaMscL channels in vivo are pentameric, indicating this as the physiologically relevant and functional oligomeric state. Complementing our in vivo results, we purified SaMscL and assessed its oligomeric state using three independent approaches (sedimentation equilibrium centrifugation, crosslinking, and light scattering) and established that SaMscL is a pentamer when solubilized in Triton X-100 and C8E5 detergents. However, performing similar experiments on SaMscL solubilized in LDAO, the detergent used in the crystallographic study, confirmed the tetrameric oligomerization resolved by X-ray crystallography. We further demonstrate that this stoichiometric shift is reversible by conventional detergent exchange experiments. Our results firmly establish the pentameric organization of SaMscL in vivo. Furthermore they demonstrate that detergents can alter the subunit stoichiometry of membrane protein complexes in vitro; thus, in vivo assays are necessary to firmly establish a membrane protein's true functionally relevant oligomeric state.
properties.summary: This study addressed the long-standing debate regarding the oligomeric state of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscL, specifically in *S. aureus* (SaMscL), which had conflicting tetrameric (crystallographic) and pentameric (other studies) models. Using a novel disulfide-trapping approach, researchers discovered that virtually all SaMscL channels in vivo are pentameric, indicating this as the physiologically relevant state. Complementary in vitro analyses showed SaMscL is pentameric in Triton X-100 and C8E5 detergents but reversibly shifts to a tetrameric state when solubilized in LDAO, the detergent used in previous crystallographic studies.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this publication makes a significant contribution by definitively establishing the in vivo pentameric organization of SaMscL, a paradigm for mechanosensation, and importantly, highlights a critical methodological caveat in membrane protein structural biology. It demonstrates that detergents can alter protein subunit stoichiometry in vitro, necessitating in vivo validation for functionally relevant states. While not directly detailing applications for space missions or astronaut health, understanding fundamental cellular mechanosensing and the challenges of membrane protein characterization has broad implications for basic biological research, drug discovery targeting membrane proteins, and potentially for understanding how biological systems respond to mechanical stress in various environments, including space. The publication in PLoS Biology by leading researchers underscores its high scientific rigor and broad impact on the field of protein biochemistry and structural biology.
properties.original_title: S. aureus MscL is a pentamer in vivo but of variable stoichiometries in vitro: implications for detergent-solubilized membrane proteins

nodes.label: Manipulating the permeation of charged compounds through the MscL nanovalve

properties.title: Manipulating the permeation of charged compounds through the MscL nanovalve
properties.abstract: MscL is a bacterial mechanosensor that serves as a biological emergency release valve, releasing cytoplasmic solutes to the environment on osmotic downshock. Previous studies have recognized that this channel has properties that make it ideal for use as a triggered nanovalve for vesicular-based targeted drug-release devices. One can even change the modality of the sensor. Briefly, the introduction of charges into the MscL pore lumen gates the channel in the absence of membrane tension; thus, by inserting compounds that acquire a charge on exposure to an alternative stimulus, such as light or pH, into the pore of the channel, controllable nanoswitches that detect these alternative modalities have been engineered. However, a charge in the pore lumen could not only encourage actuation of the nanopore but also have a significant influence on the permeation of large charged compounds, which would thus have important implications for the efficiency of drug-release devices. In this study, we used in vivo and electrophysiological approaches to demonstrate that the introduction of a charge into pore lumen of MscL does indeed influence the permeation of charged molecules. These effects were more drastic for larger compounds and, surprisingly, were related to the orientation of the MscL channel in the membrane.—Yang, L-M, Blount, P. Manipulating the permeation of charged compounds through the MscL nanovalve.
properties.summary: This study investigated how introducing a charge into the MscL pore lumen influences the permeation of charged molecules, a critical aspect for engineering bio-inspired nanovalves in drug-release devices. Researchers demonstrated that pore lumen charge significantly impacts charged molecule permeation, with more drastic effects for larger compounds and a surprising relation to the channel's membrane orientation. These findings are crucial for optimizing drug-release device efficiency and designing effective controllable nanoswitches.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this research advances understanding of mechanosensitive channel function by detailing how pore charge and channel orientation critically influence molecular permeation, providing foundational knowledge for bio-inspired nanovalve design. Practically, the insights are directly applicable to developing more efficient and controllable vesicular-based targeted drug-release devices and nanoswitches, holding potential for advanced medical technologies, including future space health applications. This work offers a robust scientific basis for engineering sophisticated bio-nanotechnology and opens avenues for further exploration in targeted delivery systems.
properties.original_title: Manipulating the permeation of charged compounds through the MscL nanovalve.

nodes.label: The oligomeric state of the truncated mechanosensitive channel of large conductance shows no varianc...

properties.title: The oligomeric state of the truncated mechanosensitive channel of large conductance shows no variance in vivo
properties.abstract: The mechanosensitive channel of large conductance (MscL) from E. coli serves as an emergency release valve allowing the cell to survive acute osmotic downshock. It is one of the best studied mechanosensitive channels and serves as a paradigm for how a protein can sense and respond to membrane tension. Two MscL crystal structures of the orthologs M. tuberculosis and S. aureus have been solved showing pentameric and tetrameric structures, respectively. Several studies followed to understand whether the discrepancy in their stoichiometry was a species difference or a consequence of the protein manipulation for crystallization. Two independent studies now agree that the full-length S. aureus MscL is actually a pentamer, not tetramer. While detergents appear to play a role in modifying the oligomeric state of the protein, a cytoplasmic helical bundle has also been implicated. Here, we evaluate the role of the C-terminal region of S. aureus MscL in the oligomerization of the channel in native membranes by using an in vivo disulfide-trapping technique. We find that the oligomeric state of S. aureus MscLs with different C-terminal truncations, including the one used to obtain the tetrameric S. aureus MscL crystal structure, are pentamers in vivo. Thus, the C-terminal domain of the S. aureus protein only plays a critical role in the oligomeric state of the SaMscL protein when it is solubilized in detergent.
properties.summary: This study investigated the role of the C-terminal region in the oligomerization of *S. aureus* mechanosensitive channel of large conductance (MscL) within native membranes. Utilizing an in vivo disulfide-trapping technique, the researchers found that *S. aureus* MscLs with various C-terminal truncations, including the one previously yielding a tetrameric crystal structure, consistently form pentamers in vivo. This finding concludes that the C-terminal domain's influence on SaMscL's oligomeric state is critical only when the protein is solubilized in detergent, not under native cellular conditions.
properties.impact: This research significantly advances the fundamental understanding of membrane protein oligomerization, particularly for mechanosensitive channels, by resolving a long-standing discrepancy in MscL stoichiometry and emphasizing the potential artifacts of *in vitro* detergent solubilization. The findings offer valuable methodological insights for future structural biology studies of membrane proteins. While originating from NASA Space Biology, this publication does not present direct practical applications for space missions, astronaut health, or countermeasures, focusing instead on core cellular and molecular mechanisms.
properties.original_title: The oligomeric state of the truncated mechanosensitive channel of large conductance shows no variance in vivo.

nodes.label: Three Routes to Modulate the Pore Size of the MscL Channel/Nanovalve

properties.title: Three Routes to Modulate the Pore Size of the MscL Channel/Nanovalve
properties.abstract: MscL is a bacterial mechanosensitive channel that protects cells from lysis upon acute decrease in external osmotic environment. It is one of the best characterized mechanosensors known, thus serving as a paradigm of how such molecules sense and respond to stimuli. In addition, the fact that it can be genetically modified, expressed, isolated, and manipulated has led to its proposed use as a triggered nanovalve for various functions including sensors within microelectronic array chips, as well as vesicular-based targeted drug release. X-ray crystallography reveals a homo-pentameric complex with each subunit containing two transmembrane α-helices (TM1 and TM2) and a single carboxyl terminal α-helix arranging within the complex to form a five-fold cytoplasmic bundle (CB), whose function and stability remain unclear. In this study, we show three routes that throttle the open channel conductance. When the linker between the TM2 and CB domain is shortened by deletions or constrained by either cross linking or heavy metal coordination, the conductance of the channel is reduced; in later two cases, even reversibly. While having implications for the stability of the CB, these data also provide routes for engineering MscL sensors that are more versatile for potential nanotech devices.
properties.summary: This study investigated three methods to modulate the pore size and conductance of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscL, a proposed nanovalve for various functions including sensors and drug release. Researchers found that shortening the linker between the TM2 and CB domain, cross-linking it, or coordinating it with heavy metals reduced the channel's conductance, with the latter two methods demonstrating reversibility. These findings provide novel routes for engineering more versatile MscL sensors for potential nanotech devices.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this work significantly advances the understanding of mechanosensitive channels and provides novel methods for precisely controlling the pore size of MscL, a paradigm mechanosensor. Practically, the findings have direct implications for developing triggered nanovalves for microelectronic array chips and vesicular-based targeted drug release, which could potentially be adapted for health monitoring or drug delivery countermeasures in space missions. Broader implications include diverse terrestrial nanotech applications and future research into advanced biosensors and controlled release systems.
properties.original_title: Three routes to modulate the pore size of the MscL channel/nanovalve

nodes.label: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interf...

properties.title: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface
properties.abstract: The bacterial mechanosensitive channel of large conductance, MscL, is one of the best characterized mechanosensitive channels serving as a paradigm for how proteins can sense and transduce mechanical forces. The physiological role of MscL is that of an emergency release valve that opens a large pore upon a sudden drop in the osmolarity of the environment. A crystal structure of a closed state of MscL shows it as a homopentamer, with each subunit consisting of two transmembrane domains (TM). There is consensus that the TM helices move in an iris like manner tilting in the plane of the membrane while gating. An N-terminal amphipathic helix that lies along the cytoplasmic membrane (S1), and the portion of TM2 near the cytoplasmic interface (TM2ci), are relatively close in the crystal structure, yet predicted to be dynamic upon gating. Here we determine how these two regions interact in the channel complex, and study how these interactions change as the channel opens. We have screened 143 double-cysteine mutants of E. coli MscL for their efficiency in disulfide bridging and generated a map of protein-protein interactions between these two regions. Interesting candidates have been further studied by patch clamp and show differences in channel activity under different redox potentials; the results suggest a model for the dynamics of these two domains during MscL gating.
properties.summary: This study investigated the dynamic protein-protein interactions between the N-terminal amphipathic helix (S1) and the TM2 cytoplasmic interface (TM2ci) of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscL during channel gating. Researchers screened 143 double-cysteine mutants of E. coli MscL to generate an interaction map, and observed differences in channel activity under varying redox potentials. The findings suggest a model for the dynamics of these two domains during MscL gating, advancing understanding of how proteins sense and transduce mechanical forces.
properties.impact: This research significantly advances the fundamental scientific understanding of mechanotransduction in bacterial cells, serving as a paradigm for mechanosensitive channels. While primarily basic cell biology, this detailed insight into cellular mechanosensation could indirectly inform NASA's Space Biology efforts by contributing to knowledge about microbial behavior and adaptation in space environments. Such foundational work may also contribute to future research exploring mechanobiology in extreme conditions or the development of novel therapeutic targets on Earth.
properties.original_title: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface

nodes.label: The MscS and MscL Families of Mechanosensitive Channels Act as Microbial Emergency Release Valves

properties.title: The MscS and MscL Families of Mechanosensitive Channels Act as Microbial Emergency Release Valves
properties.abstract: Single-celled organisms must survive exposure to environmental extremes. Perhaps one of the most variable and potentially life-threatening changes that can occur is that of a rapid and acute decrease in external osmolarity. This easily translates into several atmospheres of additional pressure that can build up within the cell. Without a protective mechanism against such pressures, the cell will lyse. Hence, most microbes appear to possess members of one or both families of bacterial mechanosensitive channels, MscS and MscL, which can act as biological emergency release valves that allow cytoplasmic solutes to be jettisoned rapidly from the cell. While this is undoubtedly a function of these proteins, the discovery of the presence of MscS homologues in plant organelles and MscL in fungus and mycoplasma genomes may complicate this simplistic interpretation of the physiology underlying these proteins. Here we compare and contrast these two mechanosensitive channel families, discuss their potential physiological roles, and review some of the most relevant data that underlie the current models for their structure and function.
properties.summary: This review article compares and contrasts the MscS and MscL families of bacterial mechanosensitive channels, which function as biological emergency release valves critical for microbial survival against rapid, acute decreases in external osmolarity that can lead to cell lysis. It highlights their role in rapidly jettisoning cytoplasmic solutes to alleviate internal pressure, while also noting the complexity introduced by the discovery of MscS homologues in plant organelles and MscL in fungus and mycoplasma genomes, suggesting broader physiological roles. The authors discuss their potential physiological functions and review current models for their structure and function.
properties.impact: This publication significantly advances fundamental cell biology by elucidating the critical mechanisms by which single-celled organisms, including microbes, survive extreme osmotic stress through mechanosensitive channels. This knowledge is invaluable for understanding microbial resilience, which has indirect but important implications for space missions, such as maintaining the health of closed-loop life support systems, controlling microbial contamination on spacecraft, or ensuring astronaut health in unique space environments. Beyond space, this research informs broader applications in biotechnology, pathogen control, and understanding stress responses in plants, opening avenues for future research into novel therapeutic targets or enhancing organismal resilience in challenging conditions.
properties.original_title: The MscS and MscL families of mechanosensitive channels act as microbial emergency release valves

nodes.label: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mech...

properties.title: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity
properties.abstract: MscL, the highly conserved bacterial mechanosensitive channel of large conductance, functionally serves as an osmotic “emergency release valve”, is among the best studied mechanosensors and a paradigm of how a channel senses and responds to membrane tension. While all homologues tested thus far encode channel activity, many show functional differences. Here we tested E. coli and S aureus chimeras and find that the periplasmic region of the protein, particularly E. coli I49 and the equivalent S aureus F47 at the periplasmic lipid-aqueous interface of the first transmembrane domain, drastically influences both the open dwell time and threshold of channel opening. One mutant shows a severe hysteresis, confirming the importance of this residue in determining the energy barriers for channel gating. We propose that this site acts similar to a spring for a clasp knife, adjusting the resistance for obtaining and stabilizing an open or closed channel structure.
properties.summary: This study investigated the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscL, a crucial osmotic 'emergency release valve' and mechanosensor, to understand how it senses and responds to membrane tension. By testing *E. coli* and *S. aureus* chimeras, the research identified that a single lipid-interface residue in the periplasmic region (E. coli I49 and S. aureus F47) drastically influences both the open dwell time and threshold of channel opening, with one mutant showing severe hysteresis. These findings suggest this residue acts as a 'spring' adjusting the energy barriers for channel gating and stabilizing channel structures.
properties.impact: Scientifically, this publication significantly advances the understanding of mechanosensation and channel gating mechanisms by pinpointing a specific lipid-interface residue critical for MscL kinetics and mechanosensitivity, thereby clarifying protein-lipid interactions. For NASA Space Biology, understanding how cells sense and respond to membrane tension and osmotic stress is fundamental to comprehending cellular adaptation and resilience in altered gravity environments, potentially informing astronaut health and countermeasures against cellular dysfunction in space. Broadly, this work provides a fundamental model for studying other mechanosensors and their roles in various biological systems, with potential implications for terrestrial diseases involving cellular mechanotransduction.
properties.original_title: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity

properties.title: Reply to Bemm et al. and Arakawa: Identifying foreign genes in independent Hypsibius dujardini genome assemblies
properties.summary: This publication, a reply by Boothby and Goldstein in PNAS, focuses on the methodology and validation of identifying foreign genes within independent genome assemblies of the tardigrade species, Hypsibius dujardini. It addresses prior discussions, likely reinforcing or clarifying the original research findings regarding the presence and identification of horizontally transferred genes in this extremophile's genome. The specific findings or statistics are not provided in the input, but the article's context points to a confirmation or refinement of genomic analysis techniques.
properties.impact: The scientific significance of this work lies in advancing the understanding of genomic architecture and horizontal gene transfer in tardigrades, a topic often debated in the field of evolutionary genomics, published in the prestigious PNAS. While not directly detailing space mission applications, research into tardigrade genomics and their remarkable adaptations, including their resilience, provides fundamental insights relevant to astrobiology and the study of life in extreme environments. It contributes to robust genomic methodologies crucial for accurate gene identification and understanding organismal biology.
